content.description:
A similar style to Genetic Mirror for the first half of the climb, followed by a cool move over a roof and a thin slabby crux passing the final bolt.

Starts just left of Genetic Mirror. The route trends leftward across the wall, with Slippery Bastard branching off to the right after the third bolt.
8 bolts.

Mostly 5.9 to 5.10a climbing, with a short 5.10b crux. Typical Skaha crimping and face climbing. Trend right near the top.



Look for the bolts below the left side of the large block above While the Crow's Away. Directly left of While the Crow's Away and right of Runcible Spoon.

9 bolts. 2 bolt anchor at the top.

This name sounds like it refers to finding a route on this wall after the good lines are all done. 
  
 It is still worth doing if you have some trad gear, especially small stoppers, I don't think I had offset brass nuts then, and they may help. It was tricky to protect. 
  
 It shares the first 5-6 meters with Runcible Spoon on the left, then wanders more right past bolts and a thin crack.

Right of Runcible Spoon up on top of a big flat boulder.
Small gear rack, can't remember how many bolts, and a bolted anchor.

A fun climb, typical of a Skaha 5.10. Incut holds, a few tricky sequences, and good rests.  At the top it trends right in some nice rock similar to glacier-polished granite (maybe it is glacier polished).  Can feel cryptic and contrived at times. When the option presents itself, generally head right. 
  
 For those pushing themselves, a stick clip is not a terrible idea, as the initial moves to the first bolt are weird.

Starts on a little ledge just left of Slices of Quince, immediately to the left of the large tree.
8 bolts, bolted anchor.

Easy climbing at the beginning leads to smaller holds up top, similar to Looking Glass.

Directly right of Looking Glass (5.10a).
10 bolts.

climbs.name: Looking Glass
climbs.fa: Howie Richardson, Tony Richardson, Robin Richardson 1995

content.description:
Crux is at the top around the second to last bolt.  Starts out fun and juggy, then gets thinner the further up you go.  Sweet for practicing balance!

The line of bolts to the left of While The Crow's Away.
12 bolts, chains at the top.

This is a pretty exciting 5.7. It was a little hard to protect near the base but is an easy slab, the roof protects really well and has good holds. The crack is jagged so if you are new to cracks you may want to tape.

Furthest right on the Corridor.
Single rack, and set of nuts - they work well in the finger crack at the roof. Bolted anchor.

A typical Skaha slabby, crimpy, enjoyable adventure to the top.



Start one meter right of the crack (The Owl and the Pussycat) and face climb past the black bolts to the top of the wall. 

10 bolts, 2 bolt face anchor with rap rings.

This is another mixed bolts and crack starting a little further right of Looking Glass. It follows a thin intermittent crack. 
  
 The rock is a bit crappy to begin with but improves as you go.

Starts at a groove next right of Looking Glass.
Single rack and bolts, bolted anchor.

The crux is probably getting off the ground. But this climb has some intersting chunky rock on the lower half that leads into completely different pollished rock on the top half that is loaded with thin edgy holds.

To the left of While the Crow's Away. Shares the start with feeding off the crumbs and splits left about 20 feet off the ground.
10 bolts and chain anchors.

Another mix of bolts and discontinuous cracks. I wandered around looking for pro placements and bolts would appear. Starts with a big cam placement.

Next right of Rats.
Single rack to #3 camalot. Bolts and bolted anchor.

The bottom moves are the hardest and then it eases up on you from there.  An awesome climb that requires technique and strength in equal measure.

9 bolts, chains at the top.

A new route in the corridor, it starts up the first couple moves of The Owl and the Pussycat and then moves right to go up a few feet left of Runcible Spoon. A bit of a squeeze job (Runcibles bolts are within reach for the first half), but good fun up top. Probably better to start on Runcible and break left after the third bolt.

Immediately right of the Owl, which is the obvious corner up and right of the tree.
10 bolts? Maybe less.

Crux is at the top where it gets very thin.  Beginning is fun climbing over the overhang.

Look for the large blocky piece with bolts on it.
9 bolts, chains at the top.
An extremely popular area because it is home to a plethora of quality 5.10s.
